intro: Linanthus floribundus subsp. hallii, commonly known as the Hall's linanthus, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is characterized by its showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is often found in desert scrub and grassland habitats. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. This subspecies is adapted to arid environments and is an important part of its local ecosystem.
